name: Mahler's 3/2 problem
rephrased: A Z-number is a nonzero real number that remains in the interval [0, 0.5) for all its fractional parts when repeatedly multiplied by (3/2).
implication_form: If a nonzero real number x satisfies the condition that the fractional part of x * (3/2)^n is less than 0.5 for all positive integers n, then x is a Z-number.
explained: Mahler's 3/2 problem is a conjecture concerning the existence of 'Z-numbers'. A Z-number is defined as any nonzero real number x such that the fractional part of x multiplied by (3/2)^n is strictly less than 1/2 for every positive integer n. The conjecture, associated with mathematician Kurt Mahler, asks whether any such nonzero real numbers exist.
related_conjectures: Problems involving fractional parts with irrational bases
Questions about the distribution of sequences defined by iterated multiplication
